trans-unit.source: Connect Azure Search with ASP.NET Web Apps | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Connect Azure Search with ASP.NET Web Apps | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Hook up an ASP.NET Web app with Azure Search. Learn how to connect, query, and render results using the .Net library or REST API.
trans-unit.target: Hook up an ASP.NET Web app with Azure Search. Learn how to connect, query, and render results using the .Net library or REST API.

trans-unit.source: How to integrate Azure Search with ASP.NET Web Apps
trans-unit.target: How to integrate Azure Search with ASP.NET Web Apps

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET is the predominant web application framework in custom solutions that integrate with Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET is the predominant web application framework in custom solutions that integrate with Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you’ll learn how to connect your ASP.NET web app to Azure Search, ramp up on design patterns for common operations, and review a few coding practices that could help your development experience go more smoothly.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you’ll learn how to connect your ASP.NET web app to Azure Search, ramp up on design patterns for common operations, and review a few coding practices that could help your development experience go more smoothly.

trans-unit.source: Organize your code
trans-unit.target: Organize your code

trans-unit.source: Splitting your workloads up into standalone projects within the same Visual Studio solution gives you more flexibility in how you design, maintain, and run each program.
trans-unit.target: Splitting your workloads up into standalone projects within the same Visual Studio solution gives you more flexibility in how you design, maintain, and run each program.

trans-unit.source: We recommend three:
trans-unit.target: We recommend three:

trans-unit.source: Index creation code
trans-unit.target: Index creation code

trans-unit.source: Data ingestion code
trans-unit.target: Data ingestion code

trans-unit.source: User interaction code
trans-unit.target: User interaction code

trans-unit.source: In Azure Search, indexing operations and document operations – such as adding or updating documents, or executing queries – are fully independent of each other.
trans-unit.target: In Azure Search, indexing operations and document operations – such as adding or updating documents, or executing queries – are fully independent of each other.

trans-unit.source: This means you can decouple index management from your ASP.NET user interaction code that formulates search requests and renders the results.
trans-unit.target: This means you can decouple index management from your ASP.NET user interaction code that formulates search requests and renders the results.

trans-unit.source: In most of our code samples, the index is both created and loaded in one project (referred to as DataIndexer, CatalogIndexer, or DataCatalog in various samples), while the code that handles search requests and responses is placed in an ASP.NET MVC application project.
trans-unit.target: In most of our code samples, the index is both created and loaded in one project (referred to as DataIndexer, CatalogIndexer, or DataCatalog in various samples), while the code that handles search requests and responses is placed in an ASP.NET MVC application project.

trans-unit.source: In code samples, its practical to bundle index creation and document upload in one project, but production code would probably isolate these operations.
trans-unit.target: In code samples, its practical to bundle index creation and document upload in one project, but production code would probably isolate these operations.

trans-unit.source: Once an index is created, it’s rarely changed (and if it does change, it needs to be rebuilt), whereas documents are likely to be refreshed on a recurring basis.
trans-unit.target: Once an index is created, it’s rarely changed (and if it does change, it needs to be rebuilt), whereas documents are likely to be refreshed on a recurring basis.

trans-unit.source: Separating the workloads provides other advantages in the form of different levels of permissions for Azure Search (full admin rights versus query-only rights), use of different programming languages, more specific dependencies per program, plus the ability to revise programs independently or create multiple front-end applications that all operate on the index built and maintained by a central indexing application.
trans-unit.target: Separating the workloads provides other advantages in the form of different levels of permissions for Azure Search (full admin rights versus query-only rights), use of different programming languages, more specific dependencies per program, plus the ability to revise programs independently or create multiple front-end applications that all operate on the index built and maintained by a central indexing application.

trans-unit.source: Samples and demos using ASP.NET and Azure Search
trans-unit.target: Samples and demos using ASP.NET and Azure Search

trans-unit.source: Several code samples already exist that show how Search integrates with ASP.NET.
trans-unit.target: Several code samples already exist that show how Search integrates with ASP.NET.

trans-unit.source: You can go straight to code or a demo app by visiting any of these links:
trans-unit.target: You can go straight to code or a demo app by visiting any of these links:

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>New York City (NYC) jobs demo site</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Try App Service + Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Complete list of videos, tutorials, demos, and code samples</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: Connect to the service
trans-unit.target: Connect to the service

trans-unit.source: To establish a connection to the service and issue requests, your Web application only needs three things:
trans-unit.target: To establish a connection to the service and issue requests, your Web application only needs three things:

trans-unit.source: A URL to the Azure Search service you’ve provisioned, formatted as https://<html></html>.search.windows.net
trans-unit.target: A URL to the Azure Search service you’ve provisioned, formatted as https://<html></html>.search.windows.net

trans-unit.source: An API key (GUID) that authenticates the connection to Azure Search
trans-unit.target: An API key (GUID) that authenticates the connection to Azure Search

trans-unit.source: An HTTPClient or SearchServiceClient to formulate the connection request
trans-unit.target: An HTTPClient or SearchServiceClient to formulate the connection request

trans-unit.source: URLs and API Keys
trans-unit.target: URLs and API Keys

trans-unit.source: You can find the URL and API key in the <link><linkText>portal</linkText><title></title></link> or retrieve them programmatically using the <link><linkText>Management REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can find the URL and API key in the <link><linkText>portal</linkText><title></title></link> or retrieve them programmatically using the <link><linkText>Management REST API</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Typically, both URL and key are placed in the web.config file of your user interaction program:
trans-unit.target: Typically, both URL and key are placed in the web.config file of your user interaction program:

trans-unit.source: The Search service name can be the short name you specified during provisioning as long as you append the domain (search.windows.net) on the connection, or you could specify the fully qualified name (<html></html>.search.windows.net) in web.config, without the HTTPS prefix.
trans-unit.target: The Search service name can be the short name you specified during provisioning as long as you append the domain (search.windows.net) on the connection, or you could specify the fully qualified name (<html></html>.search.windows.net) in web.config, without the HTTPS prefix.

trans-unit.source: The API key is an authentication token generated during service provisioning (admin keys only) or generated by hand if you are creating query keys in the portal.
trans-unit.target: The API key is an authentication token generated during service provisioning (admin keys only) or generated by hand if you are creating query keys in the portal.

trans-unit.source: The type of key determines which search operations are available to your application:
trans-unit.target: The type of key determines which search operations are available to your application:

trans-unit.source: admin keys (read-write permissions, 2 per service)
trans-unit.target: admin keys (read-write permissions, 2 per service)

trans-unit.source: query keys (read-only, up to 50 per service)
trans-unit.target: query keys (read-only, up to 50 per service)

trans-unit.source: All API keys are GUIDs.
trans-unit.target: All API keys are GUIDs.

trans-unit.source: Visually, there is no distinction between admin and query keys.
trans-unit.target: Visually, there is no distinction between admin and query keys.

trans-unit.source: You would need to check the portal or use the Management REST API to determine the type of key.
trans-unit.target: You would need to check the portal or use the Management REST API to determine the type of key.

trans-unit.source: A query key delivers a read-only experience to the client.
trans-unit.target: A query key delivers a read-only experience to the client.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>TryAppService + Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link> to test-drive the Azure Search operations that are available in a read-only service.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>TryAppService + Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link> to test-drive the Azure Search operations that are available in a read-only service.

trans-unit.source: Note that in TryAppService, the Web app code is fully modifiable – you can change any of the C# code in the ASP.NET project to modify web page layout, search query construction, or search results—it’s just the Azure Search service index and document load operations that are read-only, per the inclusion of a query api-key on the service connection.
trans-unit.target: Note that in TryAppService, the Web app code is fully modifiable – you can change any of the C# code in the ASP.NET project to modify web page layout, search query construction, or search results—it’s just the Azure Search service index and document load operations that are read-only, per the inclusion of a query api-key on the service connection.

trans-unit.source: Client Connection
trans-unit.target: Client Connection

trans-unit.source: The next two code snippets set up a connection to the Search service using the URL and API key.
trans-unit.target: The next two code snippets set up a connection to the Search service using the URL and API key.

trans-unit.source: Recall that the service name and API keys are specified in web.config file.
trans-unit.target: Recall that the service name and API keys are specified in web.config file.

trans-unit.source: For REST calls, admin keys must be passed in the request header, while query keys could be passed in the header or directly in the URL.
trans-unit.target: For REST calls, admin keys must be passed in the request header, while query keys could be passed in the header or directly in the URL.

trans-unit.source: **<link><linkText>HttpClient</linkText><title></title></link> with REST API calls**
trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>HttpClient</linkText><title></title></link> with REST API calls**

trans-unit.target: **<link><linkText>SearchServiceClient</linkText><title></title></link> with .NET**

trans-unit.source: Design patterns
trans-unit.target: Design patterns

trans-unit.source: A Web app that integrates with Azure Search will need to formulate queries and render the results.
trans-unit.target: A Web app that integrates with Azure Search will need to formulate queries and render the results.

trans-unit.source: This section provides guidance on how to structure code for tasks executed in a program that contains user interaction code.
trans-unit.target: This section provides guidance on how to structure code for tasks executed in a program that contains user interaction code.

trans-unit.source: Schema definition, index generation, and data ingestion are purposely excluded.
trans-unit.target: Schema definition, index generation, and data ingestion are purposely excluded.

trans-unit.source: For guidance on how to code those operations, see the walkthroughs and samples listed in <link><linkText>Videos, samples, and tutorials in Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For guidance on how to code those operations, see the walkthroughs and samples listed in <link><linkText>Videos, samples, and tutorials in Azure Search</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Query formulation
trans-unit.target: Query formulation

trans-unit.source: A full-text search over your index is executed on fields marked as isSearchable in the schema that defines the index.
trans-unit.target: A full-text search over your index is executed on fields marked as isSearchable in the schema that defines the index.

trans-unit.source: Given a search term input (represented below by string "q"), the search engine looks for a match inside all searchable fields, and returns results from fields marked as isRetrievable.
trans-unit.target: Given a search term input (represented below by string "q"), the search engine looks for a match inside all searchable fields, and returns results from fields marked as isRetrievable.

trans-unit.source: While most fields are likely to be searchable, an index could contain fields used only in filter expressions, in which case you would mark them as non-searchable to exclude them from full-text search and non-retrievable to exclude them from the search results.
trans-unit.target: While most fields are likely to be searchable, an index could contain fields used only in filter expressions, in which case you would mark them as non-searchable to exclude them from full-text search and non-retrievable to exclude them from the search results.

trans-unit.source: A search query wraps the input term provided by the user into a Search request that specifies the target index, plus parameters used to filter or refine the request.
trans-unit.target: A search query wraps the input term provided by the user into a Search request that specifies the target index, plus parameters used to filter or refine the request.

trans-unit.source: Operators embedded within the search string, such as +, - or |, are handled automatically, which means there are no coding requirements for parsing a search term.
trans-unit.target: Operators embedded within the search string, such as +, - or |, are handled automatically, which means there are no coding requirements for parsing a search term.

trans-unit.source: Any parsing is done by the search engine, as an internal operation.
trans-unit.target: Any parsing is done by the search engine, as an internal operation.

trans-unit.source: You can assume that the string you pass in will be parsed and analyzed by the engine.
trans-unit.target: You can assume that the string you pass in will be parsed and analyzed by the engine.

trans-unit.source: A search query comes in two flavors: Search or Suggestions.
trans-unit.target: A search query comes in two flavors: Search or Suggestions.

trans-unit.source: You would define separate methods for each type of query.
trans-unit.target: You would define separate methods for each type of query.

trans-unit.source: Search is full-text search over fields in your index.
trans-unit.target: Search is full-text search over fields in your index.

trans-unit.source: Suggestions is the type-ahead or auto-complete query feature in Azure Search that builds a list of potential search terms based on the first three characters of user input.
trans-unit.target: Suggestions is the type-ahead or auto-complete query feature in Azure Search that builds a list of potential search terms based on the first three characters of user input.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, you would constrain Suggestions to just those fields that contain relatively unique or distinctive values (like a product or publication name), as opposed to a fields that contain undifferentiated data.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, you would constrain Suggestions to just those fields that contain relatively unique or distinctive values (like a product or publication name), as opposed to a fields that contain undifferentiated data.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet captures a search term input in a program that uses the REST API.
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet captures a search term input in a program that uses the REST API.

trans-unit.source: The input term is represented by string q, and the remaining parameters are used to pass in filter values from a faceted navigation structure on the same search page.
trans-unit.target: The input term is represented by string q, and the remaining parameters are used to pass in filter values from a faceted navigation structure on the same search page.

trans-unit.source: Both the input term and filter parameters are used in the Search method.
trans-unit.target: Both the input term and filter parameters are used in the Search method.

trans-unit.source: The Search method that accepts this query is defined as follows.
trans-unit.target: The Search method that accepts this query is defined as follows.

trans-unit.source: Notice that it defines the parameters on the query string, plus the faceted navigation structure (supported through filters that do the heavy lifting on narrowing search results), and sort order.
trans-unit.target: Notice that it defines the parameters on the query string, plus the faceted navigation structure (supported through filters that do the heavy lifting on narrowing search results), and sort order.

trans-unit.source: A .NET method that constructs a search string could be placed in an MVC view or in a controller.
trans-unit.target: A .NET method that constructs a search string could be placed in an MVC view or in a controller.

trans-unit.source: This function passes the string to the Home controller.
trans-unit.target: This function passes the string to the Home controller.

trans-unit.source: It also defines a data structure for the results.
trans-unit.target: It also defines a data structure for the results.

trans-unit.source: A .NET method for invoking Search might look like this, contained in the main C# program that provides the connection and search operation:
trans-unit.target: A .NET method for invoking Search might look like this, contained in the main C# program that provides the connection and search operation:

trans-unit.source: Handling search results
trans-unit.target: Handling search results

trans-unit.source: Search results are returned as a rowset composed of fields that are marked in the index schema as isRetrievable.
trans-unit.target: Search results are returned as a rowset composed of fields that are marked in the index schema as isRetrievable.

trans-unit.source: One of the simpler ways to render a result set is by using the ViewBag system object in MVC.
trans-unit.target: One of the simpler ways to render a result set is by using the ViewBag system object in MVC.

trans-unit.source: The following code snippet is from Index.cshtml in the <link><linkText>AdventureWorksDemo project on CodePlex</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The following code snippet is from Index.cshtml in the <link><linkText>AdventureWorksDemo project on CodePlex</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Faceted navigation
trans-unit.target: Faceted navigation

trans-unit.source: In the same Index.cshmtl file, you can find the HTML used to build a faceted navigation structure that provides classifications for self-directed filtering, progressively narrowing search results by color, price or category.
trans-unit.target: In the same Index.cshmtl file, you can find the HTML used to build a faceted navigation structure that provides classifications for self-directed filtering, progressively narrowing search results by color, price or category.

trans-unit.source: Hit highlighting
trans-unit.target: Hit highlighting

trans-unit.source: Applying a style to the instance of the search term in a search result is called hit highlighting.
trans-unit.target: Applying a style to the instance of the search term in a search result is called hit highlighting.

trans-unit.source: In Azure Search, hit highlights are specified in the query, via the highlight search parameter, to which you give a comma-delimited list of fields to scan for matching terms.
trans-unit.target: In Azure Search, hit highlights are specified in the query, via the highlight search parameter, to which you give a comma-delimited list of fields to scan for matching terms.

trans-unit.source: The actual style you apply is up to you.
trans-unit.target: The actual style you apply is up to you.

trans-unit.source: The following three code snippets are from the <link><linkText>TryAppService + Azure Search tutorial</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The following three code snippets are from the <link><linkText>TryAppService + Azure Search tutorial</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: First, specify hit highlights as a search parameter and list the fields to check for matching terms.
trans-unit.target: First, specify hit highlights as a search parameter and list the fields to check for matching terms.

trans-unit.source: Specify the HTML style to use on hit highlight.
trans-unit.target: Specify the HTML style to use on hit highlight.

trans-unit.source: Next, iterate through the search results to find the string that needs to be highlighted.
trans-unit.target: Next, iterate through the search results to find the string that needs to be highlighted.

trans-unit.source: private HtmlString RenderHitHighlightedString(SearchResult item, string fieldName)
trans-unit.target: private HtmlString RenderHitHighlightedString(SearchResult item, string fieldName)

trans-unit.source: Last, provide the layout of the search results, specifying the result set that was evaluated in the previous snippet.
trans-unit.target: Last, provide the layout of the search results, specifying the result set that was evaluated in the previous snippet.

trans-unit.source: Common coding practices
trans-unit.target: Common coding practices

trans-unit.source: New to MVC, .NET programming, or REST APIs?
trans-unit.target: New to MVC, .NET programming, or REST APIs?

trans-unit.source: These sections offer a few coding practices to help you get up to speed.
trans-unit.target: These sections offer a few coding practices to help you get up to speed.

trans-unit.source: MVC template
trans-unit.target: MVC template

trans-unit.source: The following table summarizes how MVC template components are used in applications that include Azure Search.
trans-unit.target: The following table summarizes how MVC template components are used in applications that include Azure Search.

trans-unit.source: If you’re using MVC 4 or MVC 5, code that integrates Azure Search will generally be added to these modules
trans-unit.target: If you’re using MVC 4 or MVC 5, code that integrates Azure Search will generally be added to these modules

trans-unit.source: File
trans-unit.target: File

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Web.config
trans-unit.target: Web.config

trans-unit.source: Provide the service URL and api-key.
trans-unit.target: Provide the service URL and api-key.

trans-unit.source: Add a reference to System.Configuration in your main program module to read the values.
trans-unit.target: Add a reference to System.Configuration in your main program module to read the values.

trans-unit.source: Program.cs
trans-unit.target: Program.cs

trans-unit.source: In the main program, set up an HttpClient or SearchServiceClient to establish a connection to the service.
trans-unit.target: In the main program, set up an HttpClient or SearchServiceClient to establish a connection to the service.

trans-unit.source: Add the Search method to this program.
trans-unit.target: Add the Search method to this program.

trans-unit.source: DataModel
trans-unit.target: DataModel

trans-unit.source: Not used.
trans-unit.target: Not used.

trans-unit.source: Assuming that index creation and data load operations are in different programs, no data model is required for Azure Search in your web application.
trans-unit.target: Assuming that index creation and data load operations are in different programs, no data model is required for Azure Search in your web application.

trans-unit.source: Views
trans-unit.target: Views

trans-unit.source: A view contains the HTML for the application web page, from search box input to dynamic HTML for handling search results.
trans-unit.target: A view contains the HTML for the application web page, from search box input to dynamic HTML for handling search results.

trans-unit.source: Controllers
trans-unit.target: Controllers

trans-unit.source: Query construction and error handling is typically found in the HomeContoller.cs.
trans-unit.target: Query construction and error handling is typically found in the HomeContoller.cs.

trans-unit.source: At a minimum, the controller should include a search method that retrieves results from Azure Search and forwards the result set to the view.
trans-unit.target: At a minimum, the controller should include a search method that retrieves results from Azure Search and forwards the result set to the view.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, if you are using suggestions for auto-complete queries, you would include a method that returns suggested queries, depending on whether your index contains a matching value to the search term input provided by the user.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, if you are using suggestions for auto-complete queries, you would include a method that returns suggested queries, depending on whether your index contains a matching value to the search term input provided by the user.

trans-unit.source: When to use the .NET client library vs. REST API
trans-unit.target: When to use the .NET client library vs. REST API

trans-unit.source: For ASP.NET applications, the .NET client library is considered a better choice because it sets up the HTTP connection and handles JSON serialization and deserialization for you, which simplifies your code.
trans-unit.target: For ASP.NET applications, the .NET client library is considered a better choice because it sets up the HTTP connection and handles JSON serialization and deserialization for you, which simplifies your code.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, your choice of API might be dictated by feature parity between the two approaches.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, your choice of API might be dictated by feature parity between the two approaches.

trans-unit.source: Generally, the <link><linkText>.NET client library</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link> are interchangeable so long as the operations you require are implemented in both.
trans-unit.target: Generally, the <link><linkText>.NET client library</linkText><title></title></link> and <link><linkText>Service REST API</linkText><title></title></link> are interchangeable so long as the operations you require are implemented in both.

trans-unit.source: However, sometimes new features show up first in the REST API as part of a preview release, and only added to the .NET library months later.
trans-unit.target: However, sometimes new features show up first in the REST API as part of a preview release, and only added to the .NET library months later.

trans-unit.source: For example, indexers, which are used to automate data load operations from specific data source types, appeared in preview REST API first before showing up in the client library a few months later.
trans-unit.target: For example, indexers, which are used to automate data load operations from specific data source types, appeared in preview REST API first before showing up in the client library a few months later.

trans-unit.source: Any restrictions on feature implementation are noted in feature documentation.
trans-unit.target: Any restrictions on feature implementation are noted in feature documentation.

trans-unit.source: Include AzureSearchHelper.cs for JSON serialization and deserialization in REST API
trans-unit.target: Include AzureSearchHelper.cs for JSON serialization and deserialization in REST API

trans-unit.source: Unlike the .NET library which does this step for you, the Service REST APIs must serialize and deserialize the JSON documents in the request-response exchange with the service.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the .NET library which does this step for you, the Service REST APIs must serialize and deserialize the JSON documents in the request-response exchange with the service.

trans-unit.source: JSON is the payload format for data transmission when loading or refreshing documents in the index.
trans-unit.target: JSON is the payload format for data transmission when loading or refreshing documents in the index.

trans-unit.source: Code for JSON serialization can be found in several of samples, in a file named AzureSearchHelper.cs:
trans-unit.target: Code for JSON serialization can be found in several of samples, in a file named AzureSearchHelper.cs:
